awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Point-of-Use MEMS Gas Analyzer
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will be the development of a cost-effective, user-friendly, high-performance microsystem suitable for in-field and on-site gas analysis applications. Gas analyses are a mature but still growing multi-billion dollar global market. The proposed product can have significant impact across multiple industries and disciplines, including food processing and safety, environmental monitoring, homeland security, and biomedical diagnostics. It will provide the following important benefits to diverse customers: speed for near-real time gas analysis with high performance, portability and robustness for in-field and on-site uses, low cost to purchase and maintain, ease to use, and versatility for different applications. Additionally, employment of the proposed microsystem in process and quality controls can help improve productivity while saving costs, and autonomously monitoring hazardous gases in vulnerable environments can help protect workers and the public. 

The proposed project will be a proof-of-concept study on a modular microsystem for point-of-use gas analyses. Conventional gas analysis systems are bulky, resource and energy intensive, time consuming, and expensive to purchase, operate, and maintain. Increasing demands for in-field and on-site testing of volatile organic compounds and other gas phase species call for the development of a miniaturized gas analyzer capable of overcoming these major limitations. However, there are significant technical challenges associated with such system integrations and instrument miniaturizations, which traditionally result in significant compromises to the analytical capability/performance. The proposed solution is a modular microsystem integrating multifunctional high-performance microfluidic/sensor chips in a flexible and expandable format that is suitable for mass production and versatile applications. In Phase I, different chips will be fabricated and assembled into a testing system to investigate the technical feasibility of modular design. A commercial prototype will be developed in Phase II. Successful development of the proposed product will provide opportunities to address unmet needs in a variety of markets involving gas analyses.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Through this Phase I SBIR project, Zebra Analytix developed a miniaturized modular gas chromatography (GC) system for rapid separation and detection of volatile organic compounds (VOCs). The innovation consists of a fluidic manifold with miniature valves and module housings, modules of MEMS (microelectromechanical systems) GC column and detector chips, and control electronics. Virginia Tech was the project subawardee for chip fabrication.

Technical challenges associated with MEMS column coating and chip fluidic/electrical interfacing were successfully addressed, resulting in high-performance MEMS column and interchangeable GC modules. Performance of functionalized MEMS column was first verified on a benchtop GC system with VOC standards and samples. The results demonstrated that the MEMS column compared favorably to conventional capillary GC columns (with the same coating, a similar size, and 2-fold or 9-fold length) in terms of column efficiency, resolution, sensitivity (peak detectability), and/or speed.

Upon verification of the performance of MEMS components, both column and detector chips were assembled with corresponding CNC-machined chip adapters into individual modules. The modules were further installed and tested on the fluidic manifold as modular MEMS GC, which was operated with Zebra Analytix?s proprietary firmware and software. A gas-tight seal between the manifold and modules was achieved via a simple yet reliable face-seal approach. Different coatings and coating procedures were investigated, and optimal approaches were identified for preparation of MEMS GC columns for an initial application. On the MEMS GC, separation of one solvent, one candidate internal standard, and three representative analytes (all with the same molecular weight) was completed in less than 2 minutes. The detection showed good linearity and reproducibility, as well as low nanogram-level sensitivity.

In summary, all Phase I objectives and critical milestones have been accomplished. A technically straightforward, reproducible coating method was established for preparation of high efficiency, thermally stable MEMS GC columns. Robust face seal, chip adapter, and modular system designs were created and physically implemented, yielding a functional prototype. These results support the technical feasibility of the proposed modular MEMS GC product. The MEMS column provides competitive advantages because of its high separation efficiency and speed, low power consumption, small footprint, and suitability for system miniaturization. The modular design avoids error-prone fluidic connections and facilitates swapping MEMS components for specific configurations and applications. Taken together, the modular MEMS GC provides the opportunity to address the unmet needs of diverse industries for approachable quality assurance/quality control analytics, and opens up entirely new market opportunities for which existing commercial systems are not well suited.

 


Last Modified: 11/21/2019
Modified by: Xiaoli Su
